question: Question_03_(c)
statement:
Suppose that a function $\displaystyle z = f(x, y)$ is implicitly
deï¬ned by an equation: $\displaystyle xyz + x + y^2 + z^3 = 0$

(c) If $\displaystyle f(-1, 1) < 0$, use the linear approximation in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/December_2012/Question_03_(b)}{part
(b)} to approximate $\displaystyle f(-1.02, 0.97)$.
sols:
We just plug in the values $\displaystyle (x,y) = (-1.02,0.97)$ into the
linear approximation found in part b)
$\displaystyle f(x,y) \approx -1-\frac32 (y-1)$

$\displaystyle f(-1.02,0.97)\approx -1 - \frac32 (0.97-1) = -0.955$

{[}As a quick check, recall that $\displaystyle f(-1,1) = -1$, so our
answer should be close to this (assuming our approximation is good).{]}
